Experience Sr. Solutions Architect TSA / Homeland Security November 2014  – Present (10 months) Arlington, VA (HQ) I am responsible for serving a cross between a technical architect and part of an oversight committee that reviews all technical changes that are to occur, new deployments, technical challenge and all other issues that may arise and will affect the end client. It is my responsibility to review all storage and backup and recovery requests and submit my input for approval for changes that need to be made before the process can be approved and implemented to the customer’s environment. If I notice a better way to architect a new deployment, resolve a current or ongoing issue, laying out a technical design to be deployed, I am responsible for reviewing these issues and proposals, and after careful review, either propose a different solution, recommend a different approach to a good solution, or deny a plan or approach with reasoning as to why. I must stay up on all technical storage and backup hardware and software technologies in order to serve my team and Homeland security to the best of my abilities. Technical Architect Humana April 2014  –  September 2014  (6 months) WFH Waldorf, MD / Louisville, KY Serving as the Technical Architect, it is my responsibility to report directly to management with solutions that will address current and future needs whether that is a hardware in EMC, IBM, Flash technologies other additional storage vendors such as NetApp, HDS, 3PAR as well as looking at different solutions such as AWS (Amazon Web Services) which Humana is currently doing a proof of concept (POC) or other software solutions. While looking at all the needs within Humana and the vast array of hardware onsite such as block or file storage arrays (VMax, VPlex, Isilon, Centerra, VNX file/Block, DataDomain, IBM DS8870, FLASH technology (Pure Storage, Violin, EMC XtremIO, IBM TM), SRM tools (EMC ViPR SRM, IBM TPC, and many other 3rd party vendor SRM monitoring tools and technologies. It is my responsibility to search for new technologies that will address these needs and trends along with trying to keep within the budget guidelines and constraints. It is my responsibility to manage and set up meetings and demonstrations with vendors to explore the capabilities of the hardware or software product and relate this information to how this solution will benefit Humana’s needs. A determination is made after the data gathering is complete, and if the solution addresses the prior set requirements and is deemed a viable solution worth pursuing, additional meetings will be scheduled and additional internal resources will be brought in for review further. Engaging with and working very closely with our internal and external customers and vendors to build ongoing relationships to leverage those relationships in a professional manner in order to better serve Humana to provide the solutions that address our storage and productivity requirements. Sr. Solutions Architect Global Science & Technologies / NOAA March 2010  –  April 2014  (4 years 2 months) This was a very exciting position and time with GST/NOAA. Upon coming onboard, NOAA had just upgraded their storage environment to 15 new EMC Clariion Storage Arrays (2PB). There was a prior situation that occurred before my coming onboard, NOAA was behind schedule and really needed someone who could come on board and hit the ground running in order to ensure these arrays were ready to ingest daily data requirements from multiple satellites.I was able to meet with both management and administrators to gain pertinent knowledge on each file system in order to better aid me in how best to structure each file system, RAID levels, along with different levels of tiering, zoning and port assignments. 
During this time, I provided upper management with historical analysis on each arrays capacity and performance and resolve any issues that arose. There were many times that I was called upon to perform large data migrations either to consolidate, reduce data center foot print and resources. I was very successful in the designing, architecting and migrating large amounts of data with no impact or downtime to any of our environments using various tools to accomplish this.Seeing as government funding was limited, I was constantly searching for ways to save and cut costs. One of those projects saved NOAA over $1.6M in annual maintenance costs on hardware. Over the years, I met with EMC & NetApp regularly to discuss new technologies that could be brought into NOAA. After some careful planning and working with the vendors on budget restraints we had before us, I was able to help bring in NetApp filers, VNX/VNXe arrays and Isilon. Sr. Solutions Architect EMC November 2008  –  November 2009  (1 year 1 month) Reston, VA Being the lead Clariion Replication Manager Matter expert, I managed over 300 replication manager jobs successfully, took their success rate from 40% up to 97%. Assisted with managing additional storage arrays, throughout their environment, provided detailed configuration and design documents, as well as being the main point of contact for any and all disaster recovery issues internationally. Sr. Solutions Architect Cisco -EMC September 2008  –  November 2008  (3 months) Raleigh, NC This position was geared towards me taking a position in India to be the lead Sr. Storage Manager. My responsibilities here were to be the lead architect on Symmetrix, Connextrix, Clariion & DMX storage arrays. Provisioning storage out to other departments within Cisco, along with SRDF redundancy, Clariion Replication Manager, Powerpath, along with managing a small team of 12 people. I excelled very well at this position, but because of outside circumstances, another position came along that I decided would be a better fit for the longer term. Sr. Solutions Architect Hilton – EMC (Contract) May 2008  –  August 2008  (4 months) Memphis, TN Being the lead architect for multiple Data migrations, consolidations and repurpose as this clients lease time was expiring from 10 Clariion CX 700’s and down to only 5 CX3-80’s, with additional servers being added, it was key to design scripts to automate SnapView for Indexing servers with received information from the master server along with the scripting for creating and decommissioning on the customers 4 Cisco MDS 9513’s. Other responsibilities were automating MirrorView using replication manager and scheduling clones for disaster recovery. Hilton had a variety of operating systems such as AIX, Solaris, Windows and VMware. Working directly with the client in all aspects of the project as well as in-depth knowledge transfer, and making sure all deadlines are met, it was my responsibility to verify no mistakes were made as this client could afford little to no downtime. Technology Deployment Manager (TDM) Wachovia June 2007  –  December 2007  (7 months) Charlotte, North Carolina Area •	The DCPR TDM’s ensure that all the appropriate technical resources take part in and are represented in the DCPR analysis and/or move process. This includes ensuring that Windows and UNIX SA’s, DBA’s, LAN, Storage, and Network staff are invited to and attend the Technical Analysis / Work review sessions. The TDM participates in these sessions and ensures that complete analysis occurs during the Tech session and verification of the accurate representation of current and future states in documentation deliverables during the Work session. It is our role to manage all aspects of all projects from Symmetrix/DMX installation, migrations from DMX to Clariion, new server installations for clients, Virtual server hotel implementations; it is our role to manage these implementations as well as keeping the client up to date on all phases and aspects. Managed all the mirrorview and clones for multiple groups to verify all fractures and synchronization was complete and accurate for our many clients. 
•	As the project proceeds into the move phase, the TDM’s will be performing the SIP and/or SDI tasks (for equipment procurement/install/configuration) and will follow up with the resources required to ensure that the deployments proceed. The DCPR process also requires TDM approval on several of the milestone deliverables (i.e. Analysis Certification, SRs, BOMs, @work request,). Sr. Solutions Architect Strategic Business Systems – Herndon, VA August 2004  –  June 2007  (2 years 11 months) Reston, Va Responsible for the design and architecture of major Clariion implementations involving data migrations including database, cluster, and flat file migrations between multiple EMC storage arrays. Vast knowledge in EMC Replication Manager (Mirrorview/Sanpview/Sancopy)and Legato Replistor and many other replication applications and procedures. In-depth working knowledge of disaster recovery planning and implementations using MirrorView, SRDF/SRDF/A, as well as complex fully redundant mesh fabrics utilizing both Enterprise and Edge fiber switches. Responsible for managing client engagements, ensuring on-time project completion, handling any and all possible technical and non-technical issues. Responsible for client’s data, knowledge transfer and assisting the client in future planning and development. Acted as the lead architect on several of the largest financial institutions’ migrations and with many of the most complex military bases in B2D, disaster recovery and performance tuning. Knowledgeable and in-depth experience in SANCopy, MirrorView, DRU, SnapView, and SnapClones. Sr. Solutions Architect EMC – Charlotte, NC (DOD Federal Region-Contractor) October 2003  –  August 2004  (11 months) Charlotte, NC Accountable for the design and implementation of complex EMC Clariion storage arrays connecting through multiple switched environments utilizing Brocade and McData Departmental and Director Fiber switches. Designed and implemented SnapView/MirrorView and SANCopy, providing clients with point-in-time backups, broad disaster recovery solutions, and minimized client backup times to tape. Many of these scenarios spanned multiple buildings or locations utilizing Long wave fiber technology. Provided clients with disk-to-disk backups resulting in decreased backup times, greater redundancy, and off loaded network bandwidth, positively affecting management times and other cost saving factors. Extensive working experience in data migrations between Clariion, Symmetrix, and DMX storage arrays. Utilized SANCopy, SRDF (Synchronous) and SRDF/A (DMX/Symmetrix). Responsible for managing all aspects of projects and client relationships while on-site, as well as reviewing the client’s infrastructure and making open decisions about possible future growth and expansion decisions. Also provided very in-depth technical knowledge transfers with clients. Sr. Solutions Architect Strategic Business Systems – Chantilly, VA November 2002  –  October 2003  (1 year) Chantilly, Va Responsible for the design, architecture, and implementation on EMC Clariion FC/CX series arrays, including travel to client sites throughout the United States implementing CX200, CX400, and CX600 fiber arrays in a zoned fabric topology. Other duties performed were complete disaster recovery solutions and complete backup production readiness implementations using Veritas Backup Exec 8.6, 9.0, NetBackup 4.5, and ArcServe. Engaged in all aspects of project management, client relations, as well as very in-depth documentation. Responsible for the design and architecture of client builds including RAID Groups, LUN layout, and storage allocation.
